class Renderer: 
 45class Renderer(object):
 46    def __init__(self, width, height, fx, fy, cx, cy, near, far, num_layers=2048):
 47        """
 48        Triangle mesh renderer.
 49
 50        Parameters:
 51            width: int
 52                Image width.
 53            height: int
 54                Image height.
 55            fx: float
 56                Focal length x.
 57            fy: float
 58                Focal length y.
 59            cx: float
 60                Principal point x.
 61            cy: float
 62                Principal point y.
 63            near: float
 64                Near plane.
 65            far: float
 66                Far plane.
 67            num_layers: int
 68                Number of layers in the depth buffer.
 69        """
 70        self.renderer_env = dr.RasterizeGLContext(output_db=True)
 71        self.num_layers = num_layers
 72        self._rasterize_partial = jax.tree_util.Partial(self._rasterize, self)
 73
 74        self.set_intrinsics(width, height, fx, fy, cx, cy, near, far)
 75
 76    @classmethod
 77    def from_intrinsics_object(cls, intrinsics):
 78        return cls(
 79            intrinsics.width,
 80            intrinsics.height,
 81            intrinsics.fx,
 82            intrinsics.fy,
 83            intrinsics.cx,
 84            intrinsics.cy,
 85            intrinsics.near,
 86            intrinsics.far,
 87        )
 88
 89    def get_intrinsics_object(self):
 90        return Intrinsics(
 91            self.width,
 92            self.height,
 93            self.fx,
 94            self.fy,
 95            self.cx,
 96            self.cy,
 97            self.near,
 98            self.far,
 99        )
100
101    def set_intrinsics(self, width, height, fx, fy, cx, cy, near, far):
102        # Wrap everything in np arrays so that downstream JAX
103        # code treats these values as constants.
104        self.width, self.height = np.array(width), np.array(height)
105        self.fx, self.fy = np.array(fx), np.array(fy)
106        self.cx, self.cy = np.array(cx), np.array(cy)
107        self.near, self.far = np.array(near), np.array(far)
108        self.resolution = np.array([height, width]).astype(jnp.int32)
109        self.projection_matrix = projection_matrix_from_intrinsics(
110            width, height, fx, fy, cx, cy, near, far
111        )
112
113    @functools.partial(jax.custom_vjp, nondiff_argnums=(0,))
114    def _rasterize(self, pose, pos, tri, ranges, projMatrix, resolution):
115        a, b = _rasterize_fwd_custom_call(
116            self, pose, pos, tri, ranges, projMatrix, resolution
117        )
118        return (a, b)
119
120    def _rasterize_fwd(self, pose, pos, tri, ranges, projMatrix, resolution):
121        rast_out, rast_out_db = _rasterize_fwd_custom_call(
122            self, pose, pos, tri, ranges, projMatrix, resolution
123        )
124        saved_tensors = (
125            pose,
126            pos,
127            tri,
128            ranges,
129            projMatrix,
130            resolution,
131            rast_out,
132            rast_out_db,
133        )
134        return (rast_out, rast_out_db), saved_tensors
135
136    def _rasterize_bwd(self, saved_tensors, diffs):
137        pose, pos, tri, ranges, projMatrix, resolution, rast_out, rast_out_db = (
138            saved_tensors
139        )
140        dy, ddb = diffs
141
142        # Don't delete! This call has the side-effect of preventing JAX from complaining when we call `grad` on a `Renderer`.
143        _rasterize_bwd_custom_call(
144            self,
145            pose,
146            pos,
147            tri,
148            ranges,
149            projMatrix,
150            resolution,
151            rast_out,
152            rast_out_db,
153            dy,
154            ddb,
155        )
156        return (
157            jnp.zeros_like(pose),
158            jnp.zeros_like(pos),
159            jnp.zeros_like(tri),
160            None,
161            None,
162            None,
163        )
164
165    _rasterize.defvjp(_rasterize_fwd, _rasterize_bwd)
166
167    def interpolate_many(self, attributes, uvs, triangle_ids, faces):
168        return _interpolate_fwd_custom_call(self, attributes, uvs, triangle_ids, faces)[
169            0
170        ]
171
172    def interpolate(self, attributes, uvs, triangle_ids, faces):
173        return self.interpolate_many(
174            attributes, uvs[None, ...], triangle_ids[None, ...], faces
175        )[0]
176
177    def rasterize_many(self, poses, vertices, faces, ranges):
178        """
179        Rasterize many scenes in parallel. For scene number S and pixel at row i and column j,
180        uvs[S, i, j] contains the u and v barycentric coordinates of the intersection point with
181        triangle index at triangle_ids[S, i, j] - 1 which is on object index object_ids[S, i, j] - 1.
182        And the z coordinate of the intersection point is z[S, i, j].
183        If the pixel's ray did not intersect any triangle, the values in corresponding pixel is 0.
184
185        Parameters:
186            poses: float array, shape (num_scenes, num_objects, 4, 4)
187                Object pose matrix.
188            vertices: float array, shape (num_vertices, 3)
189                Vertex position matrix.
190            faces: int array, shape (num_triangles, 3)
191                Faces Triangle matrix. The integers correspond to rows in the vertices matrix.
192            ranges: int array, shape (num_objects, 2)
193                Ranges matrix with the 2 elements specify start indices and counts into faces.
194        Outputs:
195            uvs: float array, shape (num_scenes, height, width, 2)
196                UV coordinates of the intersection point on the triangle. Zeros if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
197            object_ids: int array, shape (num_scenes, height, width)
198                Index + 1 of the object that this pixel ray intersections. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
199            triangle_ids: int array, shape (num_scenes, height, width)
200                Index + 1 of the triangle face that this pixel ray intersections. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
201            zs: float array, shape (num_scenes, height, width)
202                Depth of the intersection point. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
203        """
204        vertices_h = jnp.concatenate(
205            [vertices, jnp.ones((vertices.shape[0], 1))], axis=-1
206        )
207        rast_out, rast_out_aux = self._rasterize_partial(
208            poses.as_matrix(),
209            vertices_h,
210            faces,
211            ranges,
212            self.projection_matrix,
213            self.resolution,
214        )
215        uvs = rast_out[..., :2]
216        zs = rast_out[..., 3]
217        object_ids = rast_out_aux[..., 0]
218        triangle_ids = rast_out_aux[..., 1]
219        return uvs, object_ids, triangle_ids, zs
220
221    def rasterize(self, pose, vertices, faces, ranges):
222        """
223        Rasterize a singe scene.
224
225        Parameters:
226            poses: float array, shape (num_objects, 4, 4)
227                Object pose matrix.
228            vertices: float array, shape (num_vertices, 3)
229                Vertex position matrix.
230            faces: int array, shape (num_triangles, 3)
231                Faces Triangle matrix. The integers correspond to rows in the vertices matrix.
232            ranges: int array, shape (num_objects, 2)
233                Ranges matrix with the 2 elements specify start indices and counts into faces.
234        Outputs:
235            uvs: float array, shape (height, width, 2)
236                UV coordinates of the intersection point on the triangle. Zeros if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
237            object_ids: int array, shape (height, width)
238                Index + 1 of the object that this pixel ray intersections. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
239            triangle_ids: int array, shape (height, width)
240                Index + 1 of the triangle face that this pixel ray intersections. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
241            zs: float array, shape (height, width)
242                Depth of the intersection point. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
243        """
244        uvs, object_ids, triangle_ids, zs = self.rasterize_many(
245            pose[None, ...], vertices, faces, ranges
246        )
247        return uvs[0], object_ids[0], triangle_ids[0], zs[0]
248
249    def render_attribute_many(self, poses, vertices, faces, ranges, attributes):
250        """
251        Render many scenes to an image by rasterizing and then interpolating attributes.
252
253        Parameters:
254            poses: float array, shape (num_scenes, num_objects, 4, 4)
255                Object pose matrix.
256            vertices: float array, shape (num_vertices, 3)
257                Vertex position matrix.
258            faces: int array, shape (num_triangles, 3)
259                Faces Triangle matrix. The integers correspond to rows in the vertices matrix.
260            ranges: int array, shape (num_objects, 2)
261                Ranges matrix with the 2 elements specify start indices and counts into faces.
262            attributes: float array, shape (num_vertices, num_attributes)
263                Attributes corresponding to the vertices
264
265        Outputs:
266            image: float array, shape (num_scenes, height, width, num_attributes)
267                At each pixel the value is the barycentric interpolation of the attributes corresponding to the
268                3 vertices of the triangle with which the pixel's ray intersected. If the pixel's ray does not intersect
269                any triangle the value at that pixel will be 0s.
270            zs: float array, shape (num_scenes, height, width)
271                Depth of the intersection point. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
272        """
273        uvs, object_ids, triangle_ids, zs = self.rasterize_many(
274            poses, vertices, faces, ranges
275        )
276        mask = object_ids > 0
277
278        interpolated_values = self.interpolate_many(
279            attributes, uvs, triangle_ids, faces
280        )
281        image = interpolated_values * mask[..., None]
282        #  + (1 - mask[...,None]) * 1.0
283        return image, zs
284
285    def render_attribute(self, pose, vertices, faces, ranges, attributes):
286        """
287        Render a single scenes to an image by rasterizing and then interpolating attributes.
288
289        Parameters:
290            poses: float array, shape (num_objects, 4, 4)
291                Object pose matrix.
292            vertices: float array, shape (num_vertices, 3)
293                Vertex position matrix.
294            faces: int array, shape (num_triangles, 3)
295                Faces Triangle matrix. The integers correspond to rows in the vertices matrix.
296            ranges: int array, shape (num_objects, 2)
297                Ranges matrix with the 2 elements specify start indices and counts into faces.
298            attributes: float array, shape (num_vertices, num_attributes)
299                Attributes corresponding to the vertices
300
301        Outputs:
302            image: float array, shape (height, width, num_attributes)
303                At each pixel the value is the barycentric interpolation of the attributes corresponding to the
304                3 vertices of the triangle with which the pixel's ray intersected. If the pixel's ray does not intersect
305                any triangle the value at that pixel will be 0s.
306            zs: float array, shape (height, width)
307                Depth of the intersection point. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
308        """
309        image, zs = self.render_attribute_many(
310            pose[None, ...], vertices, faces, ranges, attributes
311        )
312        return image[0], zs[0]

def interpolate(self, attributes, uvs, triangle_ids, faces):

def rasterize_many(self, poses, vertices, faces, ranges): 
177    def rasterize_many(self, poses, vertices, faces, ranges):
178        """
179        Rasterize many scenes in parallel. For scene number S and pixel at row i and column j,
180        uvs[S, i, j] contains the u and v barycentric coordinates of the intersection point with
181        triangle index at triangle_ids[S, i, j] - 1 which is on object index object_ids[S, i, j] - 1.
182        And the z coordinate of the intersection point is z[S, i, j].
183        If the pixel's ray did not intersect any triangle, the values in corresponding pixel is 0.
184
185        Parameters:
186            poses: float array, shape (num_scenes, num_objects, 4, 4)
187                Object pose matrix.
188            vertices: float array, shape (num_vertices, 3)
189                Vertex position matrix.
190            faces: int array, shape (num_triangles, 3)
191                Faces Triangle matrix. The integers correspond to rows in the vertices matrix.
192            ranges: int array, shape (num_objects, 2)
193                Ranges matrix with the 2 elements specify start indices and counts into faces.
194        Outputs:
195            uvs: float array, shape (num_scenes, height, width, 2)
196                UV coordinates of the intersection point on the triangle. Zeros if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
197            object_ids: int array, shape (num_scenes, height, width)
198                Index + 1 of the object that this pixel ray intersections. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
199            triangle_ids: int array, shape (num_scenes, height, width)
200                Index + 1 of the triangle face that this pixel ray intersections. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
201            zs: float array, shape (num_scenes, height, width)
202                Depth of the intersection point. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
203        """
204        vertices_h = jnp.concatenate(
205            [vertices, jnp.ones((vertices.shape[0], 1))], axis=-1
206        )
207        rast_out, rast_out_aux = self._rasterize_partial(
208            poses.as_matrix(),
209            vertices_h,
210            faces,
211            ranges,
212            self.projection_matrix,
213            self.resolution,
214        )
215        uvs = rast_out[..., :2]
216        zs = rast_out[..., 3]
217        object_ids = rast_out_aux[..., 0]
218        triangle_ids = rast_out_aux[..., 1]
219        return uvs, object_ids, triangle_ids, zs

Rasterize many scenes in parallel. For scene number S and pixel at row i and column j, uvs[S, i, j] contains the u and v barycentric coordinates of the intersection point with triangle index at triangle_ids[S, i, j] - 1 which is on object index object_ids[S, i, j] - 1. And the z coordinate of the intersection point is z[S, i, j]. If the pixel's ray did not intersect any triangle, the values in corresponding pixel is 0.

Parameters: poses: float array, shape (num_scenes, num_objects, 4, 4) Object pose matrix. vertices: float array, shape (num_vertices, 3) Vertex position matrix. faces: int array, shape (num_triangles, 3) Faces Triangle matrix. The integers correspond to rows in the vertices matrix. ranges: int array, shape (num_objects, 2) Ranges matrix with the 2 elements specify start indices and counts into faces. Outputs: uvs: float array, shape (num_scenes, height, width, 2) UV coordinates of the intersection point on the triangle. Zeros if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle. object_ids: int array, shape (num_scenes, height, width) Index + 1 of the object that this pixel ray intersections. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle. triangle_ids: int array, shape (num_scenes, height, width) Index + 1 of the triangle face that this pixel ray intersections. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle. zs: float array, shape (num_scenes, height, width) Depth of the intersection point. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.

def render_attribute_many(self, poses, vertices, faces, ranges, attributes): 
249    def render_attribute_many(self, poses, vertices, faces, ranges, attributes):
250        """
251        Render many scenes to an image by rasterizing and then interpolating attributes.
252
253        Parameters:
254            poses: float array, shape (num_scenes, num_objects, 4, 4)
255                Object pose matrix.
256            vertices: float array, shape (num_vertices, 3)
257                Vertex position matrix.
258            faces: int array, shape (num_triangles, 3)
259                Faces Triangle matrix. The integers correspond to rows in the vertices matrix.
260            ranges: int array, shape (num_objects, 2)
261                Ranges matrix with the 2 elements specify start indices and counts into faces.
262            attributes: float array, shape (num_vertices, num_attributes)
263                Attributes corresponding to the vertices
264
265        Outputs:
266            image: float array, shape (num_scenes, height, width, num_attributes)
267                At each pixel the value is the barycentric interpolation of the attributes corresponding to the
268                3 vertices of the triangle with which the pixel's ray intersected. If the pixel's ray does not intersect
269                any triangle the value at that pixel will be 0s.
270            zs: float array, shape (num_scenes, height, width)
271                Depth of the intersection point. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
272        """
273        uvs, object_ids, triangle_ids, zs = self.rasterize_many(
274            poses, vertices, faces, ranges
275        )
276        mask = object_ids > 0
277
278        interpolated_values = self.interpolate_many(
279            attributes, uvs, triangle_ids, faces
280        )
281        image = interpolated_values * mask[..., None]
282        #  + (1 - mask[...,None]) * 1.0
283        return image, zs

Render many scenes to an image by rasterizing and then interpolating attributes.

Parameters: poses: float array, shape (num_scenes, num_objects, 4, 4) Object pose matrix. vertices: float array, shape (num_vertices, 3) Vertex position matrix. faces: int array, shape (num_triangles, 3) Faces Triangle matrix. The integers correspond to rows in the vertices matrix. ranges: int array, shape (num_objects, 2) Ranges matrix with the 2 elements specify start indices and counts into faces. attributes: float array, shape (num_vertices, num_attributes) Attributes corresponding to the vertices

Outputs: image: float array, shape (num_scenes, height, width, num_attributes) At each pixel the value is the barycentric interpolation of the attributes corresponding to the 3 vertices of the triangle with which the pixel's ray intersected. If the pixel's ray does not intersect any triangle the value at that pixel will be 0s. zs: float array, shape (num_scenes, height, width) Depth of the intersection point. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.

def render_attribute(self, pose, vertices, faces, ranges, attributes): 
285    def render_attribute(self, pose, vertices, faces, ranges, attributes):
286        """
287        Render a single scenes to an image by rasterizing and then interpolating attributes.
288
289        Parameters:
290            poses: float array, shape (num_objects, 4, 4)
291                Object pose matrix.
292            vertices: float array, shape (num_vertices, 3)
293                Vertex position matrix.
294            faces: int array, shape (num_triangles, 3)
295                Faces Triangle matrix. The integers correspond to rows in the vertices matrix.
296            ranges: int array, shape (num_objects, 2)
297                Ranges matrix with the 2 elements specify start indices and counts into faces.
298            attributes: float array, shape (num_vertices, num_attributes)
299                Attributes corresponding to the vertices
300
301        Outputs:
302            image: float array, shape (height, width, num_attributes)
303                At each pixel the value is the barycentric interpolation of the attributes corresponding to the
304                3 vertices of the triangle with which the pixel's ray intersected. If the pixel's ray does not intersect
305                any triangle the value at that pixel will be 0s.
306            zs: float array, shape (height, width)
307                Depth of the intersection point. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.
308        """
309        image, zs = self.render_attribute_many(
310            pose[None, ...], vertices, faces, ranges, attributes
311        )
312        return image[0], zs[0]

Render a single scenes to an image by rasterizing and then interpolating attributes.

Parameters: poses: float array, shape (num_objects, 4, 4) Object pose matrix. vertices: float array, shape (num_vertices, 3) Vertex position matrix. faces: int array, shape (num_triangles, 3) Faces Triangle matrix. The integers correspond to rows in the vertices matrix. ranges: int array, shape (num_objects, 2) Ranges matrix with the 2 elements specify start indices and counts into faces. attributes: float array, shape (num_vertices, num_attributes) Attributes corresponding to the vertices

Outputs: image: float array, shape (height, width, num_attributes) At each pixel the value is the barycentric interpolation of the attributes corresponding to the 3 vertices of the triangle with which the pixel's ray intersected. If the pixel's ray does not intersect any triangle the value at that pixel will be 0s. zs: float array, shape (height, width) Depth of the intersection point. Zero if the pixel ray doesn't collide a triangle.

class RendererOriginal: 
 92class RendererOriginal(object):
 93    def __init__(
 94        self,
 95        width=100,
 96        height=100,
 97        fx=75.0,
 98        fy=75.0,
 99        cx=50.0,
100        cy=50.0,
101        near=0.001,
102        far=5.0,
103        scaling=1.0,
104    ):
105        """
106        Triangle mesh renderer.
107
108        Parameters:
109            width: int
110                Image width.
111            height: int
112                Image height.
113            fx: float
114                Focal length x.
115            fy: float
116                Focal length y.
117            cx: float
118                Principal point x.
119            cy: float
120                Principal point y.
121            near: float
122                Near plane.
123            far: float
124                Far plane.
125            num_layers: int
126                Number of layers in the depth buffer.
127        """
128        self.renderer_env = dr.RasterizeGLContext(output_db=False)
129        self.set_intrinsics(
130            width * scaling,
131            height * scaling,
132            fx * scaling,
133            fy * scaling,
134            cx * scaling,
135            cy * scaling,
136            near,
137            far,
138        )
139
140    def set_intrinsics(self, width, height, fx, fy, cx, cy, near, far):
141        self.width, self.height = int(width), int(height)
142        self.fx, self.fy = fx, fy
143        self.cx, self.cy = cx, cy
144        self.near, self.far = near, far
145        self.resolution = jnp.array([height, width]).astype(jnp.int32)
146        self.projection_matrix = projection_matrix_from_intrinsics(
147            width, height, fx, fy, cx, cy, near, far
148        )
149        self.projection_matrix_t = jnp.transpose(self.projection_matrix)
150

152        return rasterize_prim(self, pos, tri)
153

155        return self.rasterize_many(pos[None, ...], tri)[0]
156
157    def rasterize_mesh(self, mesh):
158        return self.rasterize(mesh.vertices, mesh.faces)
159
160    def rasterize_original(self, pos, tri):
161        return _rasterize_fwd_custom_call(self, pos, tri, self.resolution)
162
163    def interpolate_many(self, attr, rast, faces):
164        return interpolate_prim(self, attr, rast, faces)

167        return self.interpolate_many(attr[None, ...], rast[None, ...], faces)[0]
168

170        rast = self.rasterize_many(pos, tri)
171        return self.interpolate_many(attr, rast, tri)
172
173    def render(self, pos, tri, attr):
174        return self.render_many(pos[None, ...], tri, attr[None, ...])[0]

176    def render_rgbd_many(self, pos, tri, attr):
177        return self.render_many(
178            pos, tri, jnp.concatenate([attr, pos[..., -1:]], axis=-1)

@register_pytree_node_class
class Pose: 
124@register_pytree_node_class
125class Pose:
126    """Pose class with positions and quaternions representing rotation."""
127
128    def __init__(self, position, quaternion):
129        """
130        3D rigid transformation
131
132        position: 3D translation vector
133        quaternion: 4D quaternion in xyzw
134        """
135        self._position = position
136        self._quaternion = quaternion
137
138    identity_quaternion = jnp.array([0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0])
139
140    @property
141    def unit_quaternion(self):
142        raise Warning(
143            "Use `identity_quaternion` instead, a unit quaternion is any quat with norm 1!"
144        )
145        return self.identity_quaternion
146
147    @property
148    def pos(self):
149        return self._position
150
151    position = pos
152
153    @property
154    def xyzw(self):
155        return self._quaternion
156
157    quat = xyzw
158    quaternion = xyzw
159
160    @property
161    def wxyz(self):
162        return jnp.concatenate(
163            [self.quaternion[..., 3:4], self.quaternion[..., :3]], axis=-1
164        )
165
166    @property
167    def rot(self):
168        return Rot.from_quat(self.xyzw)
169
170    def normalize(self):
171        quat = self.quat / jnp.linalg.norm(self.quat, axis=-1, keepdims=True)
172        return Pose(self.pos, quat)
173
174    def quat_in_upper_hemisphere(self):
175        quat = self.quat / jnp.linalg.norm(self.quat, axis=-1, keepdims=True)
176        quat = jnp.sign(quat[..., [3]]) * quat
177        return Pose(self.pos, quat)
178
179    def canonical(self):
180        """
181        Chooses a canonical representative for the quaternion of the pose, i.e.
182        chooses from {q, -q} s.t. q[3] >= 0. Note that if q[3]==0 there is still ambiguity.
183
184        Recall that SO(3) is isomorphic to  S^3/x~-x and
185        also to D^3/~ where x~-x for x in S^2 = \\partial D^3.
186        """
187        quat = self.quat / jnp.linalg.norm(self.quat, axis=-1, keepdims=True)
188        return Pose(self.pos, choose_good_quat(quat))
189
190    def flatten(self):
191        return self.pos, self.xyzw
192
193    def tree_flatten(self):
194        return ((self.pos, self.xyzw), None)
195
196    @classmethod
197    def tree_unflatten(cls, aux_data, children):
198        return cls(*children)
199
200    def copy(self):
201        return Pose(jnp.array(self.pos), jnp.array(self.quat))
202
203    @property
204    def flat(self):
205        return self.flatten()
206
207    @property
208    def shape(self):
209        return self.pos.shape[:-1]
210
211    def reshape(self, *args):
212        shape = jax.tree.leaves(args)
213        return Pose(self.pos.reshape(shape + [3]), self.quat.reshape(shape + [4]))
214
215    def __len__(self):
216        return self.pos.shape[0]
217
218    def __iter__(self):
219        self.current = 0
220        return self
221
222    def __next__(self):
223        self.current += 1
224        if self.current <= len(self):
225            return self[self.current - 1]
226        raise StopIteration
227
228    def __getitem__(self, index):
229        return Pose(self.pos[index], self.quat[index])
230
231    def slice(self, i):
232        return Pose(self.pos[i], self.quat[i])
233
234    def as_matrix(self):
235        """Return a 4x4 pose matrix."""
236        pose_matrix = jnp.zeros((*self.pos.shape[:-1], 4, 4))
237        pose_matrix = pose_matrix.at[..., :3, :3].set(
238            Rot.from_quat(self.xyzw).as_matrix()
239        )
240        pose_matrix = pose_matrix.at[..., :3, 3].set(self.pos)
241        pose_matrix = pose_matrix.at[..., 3, 3].set(1.0)
242        return pose_matrix
243
244    @staticmethod
245    def identity():
246        """Return the identity transformation."""
247        return Pose(jnp.zeros(3), jnp.array([0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0]))
248
249    eye = identity
250    id = identity
251
252    def apply(self, vec: Array) -> Array:
253        """Apply pose to vectors."""
254        return Rot.from_quat(self.xyzw).apply(vec) + self.pos
255
256    def __call__(self, vec: Array) -> Array:
257        """Apply pose to vectors."""
258        return self.apply(vec)
259
260    def compose(self, pose: "Pose") -> "Pose":
261        """Compose with other pose."""
262        return Pose(self.apply(pose.pos), multiply_quats(self.xyzw, pose.xyzw))
263
264    def __add__(self, pose: "Pose") -> "Pose":
265        # NOTE: this is useful for gradient updates.
266        return Pose(self.pos + pose.pos, self.quat + pose.quat)
267
268    def __sub__(self, pose: "Pose") -> "Pose":
269        # NOTE: this is useful for gradient updates.
270        return Pose(self.pos - pose.pos, self.quat - pose.quat)
271
272    def scale(self, scale: Float) -> "Pose":
273        # NOTE: this is useful for gradient updates.
274        return Pose(self.pos * scale, self.quat * scale)
275
276    def __mul__(self, scale: Float) -> "Pose":
277        return self.scale(scale)
278
279    def __matmul__(self, pose: "Pose") -> "Pose":
280        """Compose with other poses."""
281        # TODO: Add test, in particular to lock in matmul vs mul.
282        return self.compose(pose)
283
284    @staticmethod
285    def concatenate_poses(pose_list):
286        return Pose(
287            jnp.concatenate([pose.pos for pose in pose_list], axis=0),
288            jnp.concatenate([pose.quat for pose in pose_list], axis=0),
289        )
290
291    def concat(self, poses, axis=0):
292        return Pose(
293            jnp.concatenate([self.pos, poses.pos], axis=axis),
294            jnp.concatenate([self.quat, poses.quat], axis=axis),
295        )
296
297    @staticmethod
298    def stack_poses(pose_list):
299        return Pose(
300            jnp.stack([pose.pos for pose in pose_list]),
301            jnp.stack([pose.quat for pose in pose_list]),
302        )
303
304    def split(self, n):
305        return [
306            Pose(ps, qs)
307            for (ps, qs) in zip(
308                jnp.array_split(self.pos, n), jnp.array_split(self.quat, n)
309            )
310        ]
311
312    def inv(self):
313        """
314        Inverse of pose.
315
316        Note that for rotation matrix R and
317        translation vector x we have
318        ```
319            [[ R x ]  [[ R' -R'x ]  = [[ I  0 ]
320             [ 0 1 ]]  [ 0    1  ]]      0  1 ]]
321        ```
322        where R' is the transpose of R.
323        """
324        R_inv = Rot.from_quat(self.xyzw).inv()
325        return Pose(-R_inv.apply(self.pos), R_inv.as_quat())
326
327    inverse = inv
328
329    def __str__(self):
330        return f"Pose(position={repr(self.pos)}, quaternion={repr(self.xyzw)})"
331
332    def __repr__(self):
333        return self.__str__()
334
335    @staticmethod
336    def from_matrix(matrix):
337        """Create an Pose from a 4x4 matrix."""
338        return Pose(matrix[..., :3, 3], Rot.from_matrix(matrix[..., :3, :3]).as_quat())
339
340    @staticmethod
341    def from_xyzw(xyzw):
342        """Create a pose from a quaternion. With zero translation."""
343        return Pose(jnp.zeros((*xyzw.shape[:-1], 1)), xyzw)
344
345    from_quat = from_xyzw
346
347    @staticmethod
348    def from_pos(position_vec):
349        """Create a pose from a vector. With the identity rotation."""
350        return Pose(
351            position_vec,
352            jnp.tile(jnp.array([0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0]), (*position_vec.shape[:-1], 1)),
353        )
354
355    from_translation = from_pos
356
357    @staticmethod
358    def from_vec(posxyzw):
359        """
360        Creates a Pose from a 7-vector [p_x, p_y, p_z, q_x, q_y, q_z, q_w]
361        where p is the position and q is the quaternion for the rotation.
362
363        Args:
364            posxyzw: Jax array with shape (7,)
365        """
366        return Pose(posxyzw[:3], posxyzw[3:])
367
368    @staticmethod
369    def from_pos_matrix(pos, matrix):
370        """Create an Pose from a position and a 3x3 matrix."""
371        return Pose(pos[..., :3], Rot.from_matrix(matrix[..., :3, :3]).as_quat())
372
373    # TODO: Should we keep that on the Pose class?
374    from_position_and_target = camera_from_position_and_target
375
376    sample_uniform_pose = sample_uniform_pose
377    sample_uniform_pose_vmap = jax.jit(
378        jax.vmap(sample_uniform_pose, in_axes=(0, None, None))
379    )
380    sample_gaussian_vmf_pose = sample_gaussian_vmf_pose
381    sample_gaussian_vmf_pose_jit = jax.jit(sample_gaussian_vmf_pose)
382    sample_gaussian_vmf_pose_vmap = jax.vmap(
383        sample_gaussian_vmf_pose, in_axes=(0, None, None, None)
384    )

Recall that SO(3) is isomorphic to S^3/x~-x and also to D^3/~ where x~-x for x in S^2 = \partial D^3.

235        """Return a 4x4 pose matrix."""
236        pose_matrix = jnp.zeros((*self.pos.shape[:-1], 4, 4))
237        pose_matrix = pose_matrix.at[..., :3, :3].set(
238            Rot.from_quat(self.xyzw).as_matrix()
239        )
240        pose_matrix = pose_matrix.at[..., :3, 3].set(self.pos)
241        pose_matrix = pose_matrix.at[..., 3, 3].set(1.0)
242        return pose_matrix

Return a 4x4 pose matrix.

@staticmethod
def identity():

245    def identity():
246        """Return the identity transformation."""
247        return Pose(jnp.zeros(3), jnp.array([0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0]))

def apply(self, vec: jax.Array) -> jax.Array: 
252    def apply(self, vec: Array) -> Array:
253        """Apply pose to vectors."""
254        return Rot.from_quat(self.xyzw).apply(vec) + self.pos

def compose(self, pose: Pose) -> Pose: 
260    def compose(self, pose: "Pose") -> "Pose":
261        """Compose with other pose."""
262        return Pose(self.apply(pose.pos), multiply_quats(self.xyzw, pose.xyzw))

Compose with other pose.

def scale(self, scale: jax.Array) -> Pose: 
272    def scale(self, scale: Float) -> "Pose":
273        # NOTE: this is useful for gradient updates.
274        return Pose(self.pos * scale, self.quat * scale)

def concat(self, poses, axis=0): 
291    def concat(self, poses, axis=0):
292        return Pose(

def split(self, n): 
304    def split(self, n):
305        return [
306            Pose(ps, qs)
307            for (ps, qs) in zip(
308                jnp.array_split(self.pos, n), jnp.array_split(self.quat, n)
309            )
310        ]
def inv(self): 
312    def inv(self):
313        """
314        Inverse of pose.
315
316        Note that for rotation matrix R and
317        translation vector x we have
318        ```
319            [[ R x ]  [[ R' -R'x ]  = [[ I  0 ]
320             [ 0 1 ]]  [ 0    1  ]]      0  1 ]]
321        ```
322        where R' is the transpose of R.
323        """
324        R_inv = Rot.from_quat(self.xyzw).inv()
325        return Pose(-R_inv.apply(self.pos), R_inv.as_quat())

Inverse of pose.

Note that for rotation matrix R and translation vector x we have

    [[ R x ]  [[ R' -R'x ]  = [[ I  0 ]
     [ 0 1 ]]  [ 0    1  ]]      0  1 ]]

where R' is the transpose of R.

def inverse(self):

313        """
314        Inverse of pose.
315

318        ```
319            [[ R x ]  [[ R' -R'x ]  = [[ I  0 ]
320             [ 0 1 ]]  [ 0    1  ]]      0  1 ]]
321        ```
322        where R' is the transpose of R.
323        """
324        R_inv = Rot.from_quat(self.xyzw).inv()
325        return Pose(-R_inv.apply(self.pos), R_inv.as_quat())

def from_position_and_target( position, target=Array([0., 0., 0.], dtype=float32), up=Array([0., 0., 1.], dtype=float32)): 
 99def camera_from_position_and_target(
100    position, target=jnp.array([0.0, 0.0, 0.0]), up=jnp.array([0.0, 0.0, 1.0])
101):
102    """
103    Create a camera pose at `position` with the camera-z-axis pointint at `target`.
104    Recall that in world coordinates we assume z-axis is up.
105
106    Args:
107        `position`: 3D position vector of the camera
108        `target`: 3D position vector of the point to look at
109        `up`: 3D vector pointing up.
110    """
111    z = target - position
112    z = z / jnp.linalg.norm(z)
113
114    x = jnp.cross(z, up)
115    x = x / jnp.linalg.norm(x)
116
117    y = jnp.cross(z, x)
118    y = y / jnp.linalg.norm(y)
119
120    rotation_matrix = jnp.hstack([x.reshape(-1, 1), y.reshape(-1, 1), z.reshape(-1, 1)])
121    return Pose(position, Rot.from_matrix(rotation_matrix).as_quat())

Create a camera pose at position with the camera-z-axis pointint at target. Recall that in world coordinates we assume z-axis is up.

Args: position: 3D position vector of the camera target: 3D position vector of the point to look at up: 3D vector pointing up.

@jax.jit
def sample_uniform_pose(key, low, high): 
46@jax.jit
47def sample_uniform_pose(key, low, high):
48    keys = jax.random.split(key, 2)
49    pos = jax.random.uniform(keys[0], (3,)) * (high - low) + low
50    quat = jax.random.normal(keys[1], (4,))
51    quat = quat / jnp.linalg.norm(quat)
52    return Pose(pos, quat)
@jax.jit
def sample_uniform_pose_vmap(key, low, high): 
46@jax.jit
47def sample_uniform_pose(key, low, high):
48    keys = jax.random.split(key, 2)
49    pos = jax.random.uniform(keys[0], (3,)) * (high - low) + low
50    quat = jax.random.normal(keys[1], (4,))
51    quat = quat / jnp.linalg.norm(quat)
52    return Pose(pos, quat)

Vectorized version of sample_uniform_pose. Takes similar arguments as sample_uniform_pose but with additional array axes over which sample_uniform_pose is mapped.

@jax.jit
def sample_gaussian_vmf_pose(key, mean_pose, std, concentration): 
62@jax.jit
63def sample_gaussian_vmf_pose(key, mean_pose, std, concentration):
64    """
65    Samples poses from the product of a diagonal normal distribution (for position) and
66    a generalized von Mises-Fisher distribution (for quaternion).
67
68    Note:
69    One can view the von MisesFisher distribution over the n-sphere
70    as the restriction of the normal distribution on R^{n+1}
71    to the n-sphere. From this viewpoint the concentration is
72    approximateley the inverse of the variance.
73
74    See:
75    > https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Von_Mises%E2%80%93Fisher_distribution#Relation_to_normal_distribution
76    """
77    from b3d.utils import keysplit
78
79    _, keys = keysplit(key, 1, 2)
80    var = std**2
81    x = jax.random.multivariate_normal(keys[0], mean_pose.pos, var * jnp.eye(3))
82    q = tfp.distributions.VonMisesFisher(mean_pose.quat, concentration).sample(
83        seed=keys[1]
84    )
85
86    return Pose(x, q)

Samples poses from the product of a diagonal normal distribution (for position) and a generalized von Mises-Fisher distribution (for quaternion).

Note: One can view the von MisesFisher distribution over the n-sphere as the restriction of the normal distribution on R^{n+1} to the n-sphere. From this viewpoint the concentration is approximateley the inverse of the variance.

See:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Von_Mises%E2%80%93Fisher_distribution#Relation_to_normal_distribution

@register_pytree_node_class
class MeshLibrary: 
 6@register_pytree_node_class
 7class MeshLibrary:
 8    def __init__(self, vertices, faces, ranges, attributes, vertex_index_to_object):
 9        # cumulative (renderer inputs)
10        self.vertices = vertices
11        self.faces = faces
12        self.ranges = ranges
13        self.attributes = attributes
14        self.vertex_index_to_object = vertex_index_to_object
15        self.objects = []
16
17    @staticmethod
18    def make_empty_library():
19        return MeshLibrary(
20            jnp.empty((0, 3)),
21            jnp.empty((0, 3), dtype=int),
22            jnp.empty((0, 2), dtype=int),
23            None,
24            jnp.empty((0,), dtype=int),
25        )
26
27    def tree_flatten(self):
28        return (
29            (
30                self.vertices,
31                self.faces,
32                self.ranges,
33                self.attributes,
34                self.vertex_index_to_object,
35            ),
36            None,
37        )
38
39    @classmethod
40    def tree_unflatten(cls, aux_data, children):
41        return cls(*children)
42
43    def get_object_name(self, obj_idx):
44        return self.names[obj_idx]
45
46    def get_num_objects(self):
47        return len(self.ranges)
48
49    def add_object(self, vertices, faces, attributes=None, name=None):
50        """
51        Given a new set of vertices and faces, update library.
52        The input vertices/faces should correspond to a novel object, not a
53        novel copy of an object already indexed by the library.
54        """
55        # if name is None:
56        #     name = ""
57        # self.names.append(name)
58        self.objects.append((vertices, faces, attributes))
59
60        current_length_of_vertices = len(self.vertices)
61        current_length_of_faces = len(self.faces)
62        current_length_of_ranges = len(self.ranges)
63
64        self.vertices = jnp.concatenate((self.vertices, vertices))
65        self.faces = jnp.concatenate((self.faces, faces + current_length_of_vertices))
66
67        self.vertex_index_to_object = jnp.concatenate(
68            (
69                self.vertex_index_to_object,
70                jnp.full(len(vertices), current_length_of_ranges),
71            )
72        )
73        self.ranges = jnp.concatenate(
74            (self.ranges, jnp.array([[current_length_of_faces, faces.shape[0]]]))
75        )
76
77        if attributes is not None:
78            if self.attributes is None:
79                self.attributes = attributes
80            else:
81                assert (
82                    attributes.shape[0] == vertices.shape[0]
83                ), "Attributes should be [num_vertices, num_attributes]"
84                self.attributes = jnp.concatenate((self.attributes, attributes))
85
86    def add_trimesh(self, mesh, vertex_scale_factor=1.0):
87        vertices = jnp.array(mesh.vertices) * vertex_scale_factor
88        vertices = vertices - jnp.mean(vertices, axis=0)
89        faces = jnp.array(mesh.faces)
90        vertex_colors = jnp.array(mesh.visual.to_color().vertex_colors)[..., :3] / 255.0
91        self.add_object(vertices, faces, vertex_colors)

def add_trimesh(self, mesh, vertex_scale_factor=1.0): 
86    def add_trimesh(self, mesh, vertex_scale_factor=1.0):
87        vertices = jnp.array(mesh.vertices) * vertex_scale_factor
88        vertices = vertices - jnp.mean(vertices, axis=0)

@register_pytree_node_class
class Mesh: 
100@register_pytree_node_class
101class Mesh:
102    def __init__(self, vertices, faces, vertex_attributes):
103        """The Mesh class represents a 3D triangle mesh with the shape represented in terms
104        of 3D vertices and faces that form triangles from the vertices. And, the vertex_attributes
105        are associated with each of the vertices.
106
107        vertices: jnp.ndarray of shape (N, 3) representing the 3D coordinates of the vertices.
108        faces: jnp.ndarray of shape (M, 3) representing the indices of the vertices that form the faces.
109        vertex_attributes: jnp.ndarray of shape (N, D) representing the attributes of the vertices.
110        """
111        self.vertices = vertices
112        self.faces = faces
113        self.vertex_attributes = vertex_attributes
114
115    def tree_flatten(self):
116        return ((self.vertices, self.faces, self.vertex_attributes), None)
117
118    @classmethod
119    def tree_unflatten(cls, aux_data, children):
120        return cls(*children)
121
122    def copy(mesh):
123        return Mesh(
124            jnp.copy(mesh.vertices),
125            jnp.copy(mesh.faces),
126            jnp.copy(mesh.vertex_attributes),
127        )
128
129    @staticmethod
130    def from_obj_file(path):
131        trimesh_mesh = trimesh.load_mesh(path, process=False, validate=False)
132        return Mesh.from_trimesh(trimesh_mesh)
133
134    from_obj = staticmethod(from_obj_file)
135
136    @staticmethod
137    def from_trimesh(trimesh_mesh):
138        vertices = jnp.array(trimesh_mesh.vertices)
139        faces = jnp.array(trimesh_mesh.faces)
140        if not isinstance(trimesh_mesh.visual, trimesh.visual.color.ColorVisuals):
141            vertex_colors = (
142                jnp.array(trimesh_mesh.visual.to_color().vertex_colors)[..., :3] / 255.0
143            )
144        else:
145            vertex_colors = (
146                jnp.array(trimesh_mesh.visual.vertex_colors)[..., :3] / 255.0
147            )
148        return Mesh(vertices, faces, vertex_colors)
149
150    def save(self, filename):
151        trimesh_mesh = trimesh.Trimesh(
152            self.vertices,
153            self.faces,
154            vertex_colors=np.array(self.vertex_attributes * 255).astype(np.uint8),
155        )
156        with open(filename, "w") as f:
157            f.write(
158                trimesh.exchange.obj.export_obj(
159                    trimesh_mesh, include_normals=True, include_texture=True
160                )
161            )
162
163    def transform(self, pose):
164        return transform_mesh(self, pose)
165
166    def __repr__(self) -> str:
167        return f"Mesh(vertices={self.vertices.shape[:-1]}, faces={self.faces.shape[:-1]}, vertex_attributes={self.vertex_attributes.shape[:-1]})"
168
169    def __len__(self):
170        # assert len(self.vertices.shape) == 3, "This is not a batched mesh object."
171        return self.vertices.shape[0]
172
173    def __getitem__(self, index):
174        return Mesh(
175            self.vertices[index], self.faces[index], self.vertex_attributes[index]
176        )
177
178    merge_meshes = staticmethod(merge_meshes)
179    transform_and_merge_meshes = staticmethod(transform_and_merge_meshes)
180    transform_mesh = staticmethod(transform_mesh)
181    squeeze_mesh = staticmethod(squeeze_mesh)
182    mesh_from_xyz_colors_dimensions = staticmethod(mesh_from_xyz_colors_dimensions)
183
184    def rr_visualize(self, channel):
185        rr_visualize_mesh(channel, self)
186
187    def scale(self, scale):
188        return Mesh(self.vertices * scale, self.faces, self.vertex_attributes)
189
190    @staticmethod

234                [2, 15, 5],
235                [3, 17, 21],
236                [3, 21, 10],
237            ]
238        )
239        vertex_attributes = jnp.tile(color, (len(vertices), 1))

242    @property
243    def shape(self):
244        return self.vertices.shape[:-1]
245
246    def __iter__(self):
247        self.current = 0
248        return self
249
250    def __next__(self):
251        self.current += 1
252        if self.current <= len(self):
253            return self[self.current - 1]
254        raise StopIteration
Mesh(vertices, faces, vertex_attributes) 
102    def __init__(self, vertices, faces, vertex_attributes):
103        """The Mesh class represents a 3D triangle mesh with the shape represented in terms
104        of 3D vertices and faces that form triangles from the vertices. And, the vertex_attributes
105        are associated with each of the vertices.
106
107        vertices: jnp.ndarray of shape (N, 3) representing the 3D coordinates of the vertices.
108        faces: jnp.ndarray of shape (M, 3) representing the indices of the vertices that form the faces.
109        vertex_attributes: jnp.ndarray of shape (N, D) representing the attributes of the vertices.
110        """
111        self.vertices = vertices
112        self.faces = faces
113        self.vertex_attributes = vertex_attributes

The Mesh class represents a 3D triangle mesh with the shape represented in terms of 3D vertices and faces that form triangles from the vertices. And, the vertex_attributes are associated with each of the vertices.

vertices: jnp.ndarray of shape (N, 3) representing the 3D coordinates of the vertices. faces: jnp.ndarray of shape (M, 3) representing the indices of the vertices that form the faces. vertex_attributes: jnp.ndarray of shape (N, D) representing the attributes of the vertices.

vertices
faces
vertex_attributes
def tree_flatten(self): 
115    def tree_flatten(self):
116        return ((self.vertices, self.faces, self.vertex_attributes), None)
@classmethod
def tree_unflatten(cls, aux_data, children): 
118    @classmethod
119    def tree_unflatten(cls, aux_data, children):
120        return cls(*children)
def copy(mesh):

123        return Mesh(
124            jnp.copy(mesh.vertices),
125            jnp.copy(mesh.faces),
126            jnp.copy(mesh.vertex_attributes),
127        )
@staticmethod
def from_obj_file(path): 
129    @staticmethod
130    def from_obj_file(path):
131        trimesh_mesh = trimesh.load_mesh(path, process=False, validate=False)
132        return Mesh.from_trimesh(trimesh_mesh)
@staticmethod
def from_obj(path): 
129    @staticmethod
130    def from_obj_file(path):
131        trimesh_mesh = trimesh.load_mesh(path, process=False, validate=False)
132        return Mesh.from_trimesh(trimesh_mesh)
@staticmethod
def from_trimesh(trimesh_mesh): 
136    @staticmethod
137    def from_trimesh(trimesh_mesh):
138        vertices = jnp.array(trimesh_mesh.vertices)
139        faces = jnp.array(trimesh_mesh.faces)
140        if not isinstance(trimesh_mesh.visual, trimesh.visual.color.ColorVisuals):
141            vertex_colors = (
142                jnp.array(trimesh_mesh.visual.to_color().vertex_colors)[..., :3] / 255.0
143            )
144        else:
145            vertex_colors = (
146                jnp.array(trimesh_mesh.visual.vertex_colors)[..., :3] / 255.0
147            )
148        return Mesh(vertices, faces, vertex_colors)
def save(self, filename): 
150    def save(self, filename):
151        trimesh_mesh = trimesh.Trimesh(
152            self.vertices,
153            self.faces,
154            vertex_colors=np.array(self.vertex_attributes * 255).astype(np.uint8),
155        )
156        with open(filename, "w") as f:
157            f.write(
158                trimesh.exchange.obj.export_obj(
159                    trimesh_mesh, include_normals=True, include_texture=True
160                )
161            )
def transform(self, pose): 
163    def transform(self, pose):
164        return transform_mesh(self, pose)
@jax.jit
def merge_meshes(meshes): 
12@jax.jit
13def merge_meshes(meshes):
14    vertices = jnp.concatenate([meshes[i].vertices for i in range(len(meshes))])
15    vertices_cumsum = jnp.cumsum(
16        jnp.array([0] + [meshes[i].vertices.shape[0] for i in range(len(meshes))])
17    )
18    faces = jnp.concatenate(
19        [meshes[i].faces + vertices_cumsum[i] for i in range(len(meshes))]
20    )
21    vertex_attributes = jnp.concatenate(
22        [meshes[i].vertex_attributes for i in range(len(meshes))]
23    )
24    return Mesh(vertices, faces, vertex_attributes)
@jax.jit
def transform_and_merge_meshes(meshes, poses): 
27@jax.jit
28def transform_and_merge_meshes(meshes, poses):
29    vertices = jnp.concatenate(
30        [poses[i].apply(meshes[i].vertices) for i in range(len(meshes))]
31    )
32    vertices_cumsum = jnp.cumsum(
33        jnp.array([0] + [meshes[i].vertices.shape[0] for i in range(len(meshes))])
34    )
35    faces = jnp.concatenate(
36        [meshes[i].faces + vertices_cumsum[i] for i in range(len(meshes))]
37    )
38    vertex_attributes = jnp.concatenate(
39        [meshes[i].vertex_attributes for i in range(len(meshes))]
40    )
41    return Mesh(vertices, faces, vertex_attributes)
@jax.jit
def transform_mesh(mesh, pose): 
54@jax.jit
55def transform_mesh(mesh, pose):
56    return Mesh(pose.apply(mesh.vertices), mesh.faces, mesh.vertex_attributes)
@jax.jit
def squeeze_mesh(mesh): 
44@jax.jit
45def squeeze_mesh(mesh):
46    vertices = jnp.concatenate(mesh.vertices)
47    vertices_cumsum = jnp.arange(mesh.vertices.shape[0]) * mesh.vertices.shape[1]
48    faces = jnp.concatenate(mesh.faces + vertices_cumsum[:, None, None])
49    vertex_attributes = jnp.concatenate(mesh.vertex_attributes)
50    full_mesh = b3d.mesh.Mesh(vertices, faces, vertex_attributes)
51    return full_mesh
@jax.jit
def mesh_from_xyz_colors_dimensions(xyz, colors, dimensions): 
70@jax.jit
71def mesh_from_xyz_colors_dimensions(xyz, colors, dimensions):
72    meshes = b3d.mesh.transform_mesh(
73        jax.vmap(b3d.mesh.Mesh.cube_mesh)(dimensions, colors),
74        b3d.Pose.from_translation(xyz)[:, None],
75    )
76    return b3d.mesh.Mesh.squeeze_mesh(meshes)

def scale(self, scale):
